body: It's an ugly hack, but I've moved the instantiation logic from the unifier to `type_infer`, so now the unifier is no longer exposed. I think there will be no need for that logic once we have generalization worked out.
@Ravenwater opened a separate PR regarding the changes to the other Relay doc

@tqchen this is exactly our algorithm - we cant always take the parent scope, if it is in special location (inside any branch of if/else, inside function definition, inside pattern matching), new scope have to be created.

It is indeed the LCA of all scope reference though.

I've added the description; I hope it is what you had in mind. We may, down the road, want to have some good answers (perhaps proofs) about the explicit type relations to guarantee that we won't have circular relations, etc., which I cannot (I think) reject out of hand for now.

> In particular, we also specify the order of evaluation.

@tqchen I am against this. Either the order does not matter, or, if the order matter in a *graph*, something is wrong. This behavior should be implementation-defined, simply because no code should depend on how it is order - something is wrong in the semantic level.

@tqchen updated regarding the latest comment, the tracing value explicitly sets into return value in codegen stage for trace intrinsic.

Thanks @lixiaoquan

@xieydd it's not mandatory to pass out argument. 
Without it it returns NDArray.

It is true that order does not matter in a graph. We essentially need to impose additional semantics when converting from graph to ANF to make sure such conversion deterministic. 

Having such deterministic conversion makes developers easy to reason about the consequences of the operation. Post-DFS order is a frequently used lowering rule already for graph code, so I propose that we adopt this semantics in the ToANF pass

Thanks, @slyubomirsky,  likely we can convert some of the text into comments in the type solver. It is always helpful to have good documentation on general steps.

Can you also comment on how would this change affect the lazy update of the trigger list of relations for a given type? Given that we do type solving lazily, we want to make sure that the triggered list of type relations are correctly maintained.

For example, if ```R(?x, t)``` changes to ```R((?a, ?b), t)```, we will need to remove ```?x``` from trigger list of R, but add ```?a, ?b``` to the list. Some additional comments on the lazy update algorithm would be very helpful

Added a couple of paragraphs on the trigger lists in the subsection on explicit type relations.

@jroesch Thanks for your suggestion. I am not sure if I fully understand what you said. Let's me walk through a simple example.

```
x = relay.var("x")
y = relay.var("y")
z = relay.var("z")
add = relay.add(x, y)
sub = relay.sub(add, z)
...
```
Now we what to assign `add` and `sub` to device `0` and `1`, respectively. Do you mean that users want to `on_device` like the following?
```
x = relay.var("x")
y = relay.var("y")
z = relay.var("z")
add = relay.add(x, y)
on_device(add, 0)
sub = relay.sub(add, z)
on_device(sub, 1)
...
```
Then we run the annotation pass to rewrite the program to:
```
x = relay.var("x")
y = relay.var("y")
z = relay.var("z")
add = relay.add(x, y)
copy0 = relay.device_copy(add)
sub = relay.sub(copy0, z)
copy1 = relay.device_copy(sub)
...
```
Please correct me if there is any misunderstanding. Otherwise, I have a couple of questions:

1. Are users supposed to go through the network and perform the annotation? It looks this might be handy when the network is large.
2. How should we propagate the device ids? I think one way is to propagate the device id information based in a bottom-up manner where the device_copy op should have an `device_id` attribute.
global: common binary operators have syntactic suger in the text format, e.g. `add`, `multiply`, `equal` are `+`, `*`, `==`, resp.
Ah, good, I will use that.

Curious about others' thoughts here: Should this language reference include constructs that are entirely internal and not part of the user-facing language at all? E.g., the type reporter (used for implementing relations), tempexprs (used for implementing passes), and (currently in the docs) incomplete types. It's a question of the purpose of the language ref.

Personally, I think those would be better addressed in developer guides.

Decided to go through with a large reorganization in `relay_expr`: The issue of function calls made the distinction between the dataflow and control fragments a little messy, so I put the discussion into a subsection by itself and let each expression be its own subsection.

Hey, what's up?
I received email notification about this pull request :)

You should call cpp function in python binding like https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/427e4f1bc8ffae7455b020e7d695994a7ed3e574/topi/python/topi/nn/pooling.py#L42
Then only test the cpp implementation.

But I totally agree adding new operator is not easy and error-prune. Many things have to be done in different places. Automating some parts will be good.

Thanks for the tip! I wonder if it's worth going the code generation route with AST parsers and the works. IIUC this is akin to what TF does when generating things like the math operators. This shouldn't be too difficult for the C++ side using Clang (just onerous :).

All considered, though, it's great that the Relay op registry doesn't require adding patterns and schedules in Python.

Relatedly, is there a way to ask Relay to schedule `broadcast`? `GLU` doesn't compile under Relay but does for NNVM when registered with 
```python
reg.register_schedule("glu", _fschedule_broadcast)  # <-- this is important, I think
reg.register_pattern("glu", OpPattern.INJECTIVE)
```

And finally, an outlandish proposal: clean up the codebase by removing all TOPI python ops. PyTOPI is useful for prototyping but is confusing when core ops are implemented in multiple places. With a little bit of syntactic sugar around `Array` and `Expr`, the expressiveness should be about the same.

cc @tqchen @jroesch for the simplification of adding new operators.

Relay also requires registrations in python, and you did that in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2328/files#diff-b8a5824a5a8f1907448d2588d8cd773cR15 ?

I think your proposal about moving TOPI to cpp is on our roadmap.

@tqchen can you be more specific? the fgradient signature is included in the rfc already.

> Differentiating programs that include operators requires us to register implementations of gradients for the different operators, which we will include as attributes. More specfically, for an operator f : <x0, x1, x2...> -> y, the gradient of the operator is f : <x0, x1, x2...> -> <y, y -> <x0, x1, x2...>>

Re: automatic wrapper generation.

We had a debate on whether or not we want to automate more when wrapping c++ code from python, I have done so in past related projects. The problem that we quickly encounter, however, are:

- It is hard to generate key-word argument bindings support with exactly the same signature.
   - Doing so require quite a lot of additional meta information
   - Usually, the best effort we can do still leaves things like ```myfunc(*args, **kwargs)```
- It is hard to automatically expose clear doc-strings.
- It usually confuses developer because they can not find the auto-generated function.

In summary, the automatically generated functions are OK, but not the most user-friendly ones with the right keyword argument support, and clear docs. So we made a decision to not to do so, instead:

- Always only exposes function with positional arguments (PackedFunc) to the frontend, this simplifies the complexity and indirection in FFI 
- Always create a wrapper function for user-facing APIs, with clear doc-strings.

We believe that because it is usually one-liner to add such indirection and a lot of effort was spent in making clear docs, this simplified approach will not bring too much additional burden to the developers but helps our users by a lot.

@denis0x0D thanks for the change. The logic can be improved further, here are some parts that can be improved

- The condition handling is done inside the CallPacked and is a bit obscured because the behavior depends on op's name.
- The returning of the traced value is done via load from stored argument buffer, while we could have directly done so in intrinsic handling.

Here is one possible way to improve the current logic.
- When lowering trace, keep the traced value as the last argument.
- Pass an optional return value as an argument of CallPacked, if that is not null, make sure CallPacked return the corresponding value

I would be happy to chase down the bug for you.

Sorry for a bit delay in reviewing the code. I take a serious look, and there are still some problems that need to be resolved. 

The key improvement this PR introduces is the ability to do unification on recursive data types, so when we Unify((?a, t1), (t2, ?b))```, ```?a``` will be resolved to t2 and ```?b``` will be resolved in t1. The current lazy update algorithm maintains a list of touched relations to types. See the following example

```
R1(?a, t1)
R2((?a, ?b), ?c)
R3(t2, ?c)
```

Then the desirable relations(stored in TypeNode) are:
- ?a : [R1, R2]
- ?b : [R2]
- ?c : [R2, R3]

The lazy update algorithm will add the relations to the update queue list when certain type get unified to another one. In our case, if we unify ```?a``` to ```t0```, then R1, R2 will be added to the queue.

The key problem now becomes how do we keep the relation list up to date. More importantly, how to do so when one incomplete type get unified to another one.

The previous logic of such update is done in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/relay/pass/type_solver.h#L177. In particular, when we call
```MergeFromTo(?c, ?a)```, we will add all the un-resolved relations in ?c, in this case, R2, R3 to ?a. This logic was fine previously because MergeFromTo only happens either between concrete and incomplete, or two incomplete types.

Because this PR introduces a recursive type, then it is possible to call 
```MergeFromTo((?c1, ?c2), ?a)```, in such case, we will need to also recursively add ```?a```'s pending relation to ?c1 and ?c2, instead of relying on the original logic of update, which tries to add to ```tx = (?c1, ?c2)```, and tx is not tracked.

I thought the above problem was addressed by the addition of the propagator, which ensures that all nested types list the relations from their parent types. I will see if there is a need to have further recursive merging and if I can add more test cases for such recursive updates.

Given that glu can be implemented with split+ sigmoid, would it be easier to just implement an importer that converts the glu into the composed ops?
@vinx13 ok, I'll update this pr to fuse max_elem and expsum.

The current propagator logic only solves the problem when the initial relation contains recursive ones, like ```R1((?c1, ?c2), ?a)```, but did not resolve the problem when an existing IncompleteType get unified to a tuple which also contains IncompleteType.

For example. initial condition: ```R2(?d, ?a)```, then we call ```MergeFromTo((?c1, ?c2), ?d)```
Ah, I see the issue now, very good catch. I'll work on a solution over the next day.

Most likely. I guess this was good practice at making a relay op.

Re: codegen issues, I think that with sufficient effort, the generated code can be essentially what a human would write. The only drawback would be that users would have little idea of how the files interact (other than using `help(the_function_name)` in a repl.

@vinx13 I'm getting an error at compute_at below. max_elem should be obviously the producer of expsum. Do you have any idea why? 
```
softmax = outs[0]
expsum = softmax.op.input_tensors[2]
max_elem = expsum.op.input_tensors[1]

axes = expsum.op.axis
fused = s[expsum].fuse(*axes)
bx, tx = s[expsum].split(fused, factor=num_thread)
s[max_elem].compute_at(s[expsum], tx)
```

```
tvm/src/schedule/bound.cc:168: Check failed: found_attach || stage_attach.size() == 0 Invalid Schedule, cannot find the producer compute(compute, 000001AF5B4B8070) along the loop nest specified by compute_at of consumer compute(compute, 000001AF5B4B6970)
```

@masahi I added names to compute_op and the error message is 
```
cannot find the producer compute(max_elem, 0x31de3c0) along the loop nest specified by compute_at of consumer compute(softmax, 0x31e14f0)
```
max_elem is consumed in softmax, seems that max_elem is not properly 'produced' when being attached to expsum
hmm, it's weird that we are seeing ```compute(softmax, 0x31e14f0)``` instead of expsum. Besides, max_elem IS one of the producers to softmax.
@masahi I think it is currently impossible to produce two tensors in one kernel. Let's keep using schedule_injective for now
Yeah I just realized that, since max_elem is fed into both expsum and normalize, we can't fuse max_elem into expsum.
Did you check the performance regression on resnet-18 or mobilenet?

Our model has one large softmax input previously: maxelem is [1, 204800, 1],   expsum is [1, 204800, 1] too. Could this schedule can handle this situation or not? 

My previous method is to fuse all axies and do split like this (for max_elem / expsum / softmax):
```python
    max_threads = tvm.target.current_target(allow_none=False).max_num_threads
    n, c, hw = s[max_elem].op.axis
    fused = s[max_elem].fuse(n, c, hw)
    fused, vec = s[max_elem].split(fused, 16)
    bb, tt = s[max_elem].split(fused, max_threads)
    s[max_elem].bind(bb, tvm.thread_axis("blockIdx.x"))
    s[max_elem].bind(tt, tvm.thread_axis("threadIdx.x"))
    s[max_elem].vectorize(vec)
```
My test environment is Mali-G71. The execution time could be from 900ms to 5ms.
 
Maybe this PR is better way, but I haven't tested it. But this workload should be one good test case for you.

@srkreddy1238 This is taken into account: even if a node has multiple outputs, each input of another node uses only one of them and we still have a 1-element list there: https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/021099f8d7d9cc59ae9ee872edde45803983d45c/nnvm/python/nnvm/frontend/tensorflow.py#L1235-L1243.
@merrymercy @FrozenGene This PR applies to 4D or 5D inputs only. For 2D inputs as in image classification workload, there is no change and the same existing schedule will apply.
